Since I realize it would be hard to realize my vision without being established, are there any filmmaking methods that allow for adaptability/flexibility (such as altering script on the fly ) to account for strengths you may not expect (i.e. if one actor is better than expected but was in a side role)? Did Jarmusch have a method similar to that?

Yes, there are several filmmaking methods that allow for adaptability and flexibility during the production process. One common approach is to have a script supervisor on set who can help keep track of changes to the script and make sure that continuity is maintained. Another technique is to have a rehearsal period before shooting begins, during which the director and actors can explore the material and make adjustments to the script as necessary.

In terms of Jim Jarmusch's approach, he is known for being very collaborative with his actors and often allows them to improvise or bring their own ideas to the table. He also tends to shoot his films in a more free-form style, often relying on long takes and natural lighting to capture the moment. This approach can allow for more spontaneity and improvisation on set, which can lead to unexpected but often interesting results.
Though I assume having a very firm vision will help establish authority of some sorts if not established regardless

Yes, having a clear and strong vision can definitely help establish your authority as a filmmaker, even if you are not yet established in the industry. When you have a well-thought-out vision, it can inspire confidence in your team and make it easier for everyone to work towards a common goal. However, it's also important to remain flexible and open to changes, as unexpected things can happen during the filmmaking process. Finding a balance between having a clear vision and being adaptable is key to success as a filmmaker.
So when initially starting would it potentially be wise to limit ideas to 15 minutes or so? Or is that too unambitious

Starting with shorter projects, such as a 15-minute film or a web series, can be a good way to gain experience and establish a portfolio. It can also help you to focus on developing your storytelling and filmmaking skills without being overwhelmed by the demands of a feature-length film.

Short films can still be ambitious and impactful, so I wouldn't necessarily say that limiting your ideas to 15 minutes is unambitious. In fact, many celebrated filmmakers have started with short films, including Martin Scorsese, Steven Spielberg, and George Lucas.

Ultimately, the length of your project should be dictated by the story you want to tell and what you feel is necessary to tell it effectively. If your story can be told in 15 minutes, then a short film may be the perfect format for it. If you have a larger, more complex story that requires more time to tell, then a feature-length film or series may be more appropriate.
